instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PP3V42_H3H: What is PP3V42_H3H? This is a typo of PP3V42_G3H When you see PP3V42_H3H, assume they meant to type PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos and All....
board came zith serious WD; cleaned and repair all what I could what was visual before plugging the charger; then:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 8.19V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_H3H</SIGNAL>: 3.423V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.423V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>:  0V

Reheat the SMC then I saw sparks almost flames around the <CAPACITOR>C3085</CAPACITOR> (thunderbolt) area

Removed <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C3084</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C3085</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C3096</CAPACITOR> qnd <CAPACITOR>C3097</CAPACITOR> because of short to gnd
<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL>  at 8.61V !!!!!!!!  so I've also removed <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> as Pin 1 and 4 = 8.61V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 8.61V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_H3H</SIGNAL>: 3.420V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.330V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>:  5.129V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.331V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>: 5.130V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3.331V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.331V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: 3.331V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5.129V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.328V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>: 1.835V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>: 1.228V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1.085V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.535V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>: 0.630V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.092V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>: 1.090V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 1.8V

[FONT="Calibri"]Dead CPU?[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message:
I also noticed that at <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> pin 6 , <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL> is at 0V
Then I went thru <RESISTOR>R6121</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6111</RESISTOR>: <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK_R</SIGNAL> is also at 0V which is provided by the CPU......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message: I don?t think so. If you had flames around your TBT stuff perhaps something is shorted/causing issues in that area and causing no post. All TBT stuff removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message:
SPI I/O pins must be low when PCH accesses <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, so that looks correct.
But you must check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and maybe remove J6100; sometime gets corroded and blocks the communication.
You can also try new BIOS, as sometime liquid damage cause BIOS corruption.
Maybe need to put good flux and heat CPU; no more than 180-200 degrees, just to burn eventually crap.
Ultrasonic cleaning in the end could help too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message:
[COLOR=#000000]@[/COLOR][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/1153-johnb8812"][COLOR=#000000]JohnB8812, [/COLOR][/URL]"All TBT stuff removed?"

As I've removed <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>, now I have nothing going to the THBT level, so I guess I should be OK no?
You agree that it's NOT  normal that <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> was passing (closed ) with pin 1 and 4 at the same voltage (8.61V)

[USER][/USER][COLOR=#000000] :
I've forgot to say that I succeed reading the SPI Rom with the Medusa, but only after several tries as it had difficulties to connect.
I've cleaned the ME region and PRAM area[/COLOR]

When you write: "SPI I/O pins must be low when PCH accesses <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>"
How long does that sequence take, only few seconds?
Correct me if I'm wrong but I use to remember that all SPI pins had a level of 3.3V except the 4 of course.

Also I still have NO GREEN light on the charger......which is secondary

Best Regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead CPU?
threads.message:
Write new BIOS; you could have corrupted pure BIOS area not only ME region.

SPI pins should go high on the first moment, but I/O pins will drop immediatelly and should stay low.

Test the MLB without LIO flex connected.
Once the board works, then you have time to fix Magsafe light issue.
